thread.title: JSE rebounds amid choppy global markets | Markets
thread.title_full: JSE rebounds amid choppy global markets | Markets | BDlive

author: Andries Mahlangu
title: JSE rebounds amid choppy global markets | Markets
text:
Picture: MICHAEL ETTERSHANK THE JSE staged a tentative comeback on Wednesday, with investors nibbling away at some of the industrial and financial shares.
The all share index was up 0.74% to 50,223 points in early afternoon trade, looking to end a three-day losing run that has wiped off just more than 3% in market value.
The resource complex, which in particular bore the brunt of the sell-off on Tuesday, was mostly weaker. Platinum and gold shares dropped 2.75% and 2.33%, respectively.
Commodity prices were mixed, with base metals such as copper losing nearly 4%, while the platinum spot price bounced slightly after hitting fresh six-year lows of about $927 an ounce.
"The markets will continue to be volatile until we have clarity on the magnitude of China’s slowing growth and the timing of US interest rates policy normalisation," Nedbank Private Wealth stockbroking portfolio manager Grant Gilburt said.
Europe’s major markets were mostly higher at midday after a sharply weaker session in Asia where the Hong Kong’s Hang Seng settled 2.26% lower.
Adding to the gloomy global market mood was weak Chinese manufacturing data for September. China’s Caixin "flash" manufacturing purchasing managers index slipped to 47.0 in September, coming in below expectations and reaching its lowest level since March 2009.
Among some individual shares on the JSE, South32 was off 2.5% at R13.65, with Kumba Iron Ore losing 2.09% to R84.51. Implats shed 2.88% to R41.87.
The heavily weighted media and internet group Naspers rose 1.88% to R1,718.31.
Capitec Holdings recovered 1.99% to R485.33, while Sanlam regained 2.09% to R59.52.
Mr Price picked up 2.26% to R204.50, while PPC dropped 4.15% to R18.69
